messages: c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (15:36): is there any point is specifying charset on <script> elements if it has already been defined with <meta charset="utf-8">?
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (15:37): If I set <meta charset="utf-8"> in head section, does is it mean that all resources loaded from that page will use utf-8 as well?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:38): but scripts and style sheets will inherit the encoding from the page unless they declare encoding themselves
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (15:38): will it work for CSS files? Should I start my CSS files with @charset 'utf-8'; ?
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (15:38): oh, great
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:39): (html in an iframe will need to declare its own encoding)

76680563b02870d015080e95984df8fc (15:39): Warning! This method has very idiosyncratic behavior. In some cases, this method can affect the state of the HTML parser while the parser is running, resulting in a DOM that does not correspond to the source of the document.
76680563b02870d015080e95984df8fc (15:39): this also happens when using DOM...
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (15:40): and what if I'm using XHTML5 and declare charset at the top of the document like this:
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (15:40): <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:40): is that about document.write?
76680563b02870d015080e95984df8fc (15:40): And older versions of IE also did it without doing anything...
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (15:40): do I still have to use  <meta charset="utf-8"> in head?
76680563b02870d015080e95984df8fc (15:40): c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6, charset declaration in <meta> is ignored in XML mode
76680563b02870d015080e95984df8fc (15:41): XML parser must know encoding before processing anything...
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:42): 76680563b02870d015080e95984df8fc: file a bug saying that the note should be clearer about what it means
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:42): c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6: xml defaults to utf-8 so doesn't need a declaration at all
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (15:42): 76680563b02870d015080e95984df8fc: but will  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> be also applied to scripts and stylesheets that are loaded from that page?
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (15:43): ok, let's check :P
76680563b02870d015080e95984df8fc (15:43): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, I through that XML detects encoding basing on BOM and uses UTF-8 if BOM wasn't found...
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:43): no declaration in xml will still let css and scripts inherit the used encoding

c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (16:06): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: yeah, but parsing HTML still requires a lot more trickery than regular XML

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:09): c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6: hsivonen's finding showed that namespaces cost 21% perf hit for xml while html's "fixups" only costs 7% perf hit
